The iTunes 9 UI has a strange, unlike-anything-else-in-OS-X veneer.

§ Sep 10th, 2009


WideMail and the YoJimbo widescreen hack had been doing their job silently and efficiently for so long that I totally forgot I was even using them. Snow Leopard broke Wide Mail and YoJimbo 2 broke the hack with no new option to replace the need for a hack.

They’re two of my most used applications, two of the small group I keep running all the time. It’s really disrupted my computing experience. The item list on item view layout is so inefficient and contrary to the conceptual sense it makes to drill down from left to right.

NetNewsWire defaults to the inferior layout but provides vastly superior options. I’m surprised Mail in Snow Leopard and YoJimbo 2 have persisted with the obviously inferior layout and no option to correct it.

§ Sep 8th, 2009

Mac Software Raffle Update →

In it’s first week the Mac Software Raffle has already been a huge success, raising over $700 for the JDRF. Since kicking off there’s been three great apps — TimeBoxed, 1Password and Family — added to the prize bundle along with a $10 iTunes voucher to each winner. All existing entries are in it to win the whole bundle including the new apps but if you haven’t entered yet, now’s your chance, there’s only 7 days left!

I have an irrational fear that future generations and civilisations will find music videos like this one, mistake it for documentary rather than creative, abstract entertainment and draw completely incorrect conclusions about what life used to be like in the year 2009.

§ Sep 6th, 2009

The Definitive Snow Leopard Review →

I’ve finally finished the traditional OS X major release review from John Siracusa at Ars Technica. It’s extremely long and split into a frustrating, Instapaper-unfriendly 23 (!) pages but finish it knowing there’s no need to read another article on the subject. As always it’s written in a narrative style with a number of high quality visual aids. If you’re interested in Apple, Leopard, Snow Leopard, operating systems or computers in general, it’s well worth your time.

I find this kind of of hyper-confidence hilarious.

§ Sep 6th, 2009

My new ride. A never ridden, 2006, Trek Madone sporting the Dura-Ace 7800 groupset. It’s the kind of bike pros are still riding today and it was just luck and good timing that I was able to get it at a price within my budget. It was clear after only riding it the 5km home from the bike store that it’s lightyears ahead of anything I’ve ridden before.

For now I’m using quite a high raised stem to slowly ease my spine back into cycling.

§ Sep 5th, 2009

Quicktime for YouTube

Like Sebastian I’m a long time Flash hater and ClickToFlash lover but I had no idea about it’s ability to switch out the YouTube Flash player for the native Quicktime Player. The advantages are huge: better quality, faster loading, improved tracking, invisible controls and it saves your processor working itself into a frenzy. ClickToFlash, already brilliant just got twice as good.

§ Sep 5th, 2009

Sleep

Last night I saw a friend’s band play over an hour away down the coast. I didn’t get home until after midnight but had to wake up at my usual 6am for work. Usually I get to bed at around 8.30 or 9pm and get a solid 9 hours sleep. Usually I go through 4 or 5 spells each day of uncontrollable yawning with a feeling of extreme tiredness and I never feel fully rested or as alert as I did today, after only 5 and a half hours sleep.

Amount of sleep to feeling of being rested is a parabolic function. Two hours too little or two hours too much, you’re just as tired all day. 9 hours is much more each night than anyone else I know, I’m going to start going to bed later to feel better rested with the bonus of an hour or two extra each day to get things done.

§ Sep 4th, 2009

Subtle Differences

From the day I signed up for Twitter almost three years ago I used Twitterrific. A few months ago when Tweetie was released I made the switch. It was a small learning curve but up until I recently switched back to Twitterrific, I’d totally forgotten about the differences. The most notable one and reason I switched to Tweetie in the first place is the behaviour that immediately follows an update.

Twitterrific clears the input field and not until the next timeline refresh is your tweet displayed. Tweetie posts it instantly to your timeline. One makes you question whether your tweet has been posted, the other provides instant satisfaction.

§ Sep 2nd, 2009

One thing that was very clear after all these conversations about phones is that there is no “one size fits all” in this market. On Oct. 6th, you’ll see new Windows phones designed for a variety of tastes, needs and price points - with or without keyboards, with or without touch screens, as well as your choice of GPS, accelerometer and high resolution camera.

This is what’s wrong with Microsoft, why is there a choice of GPS, accelerometer and high resolution camera? Why would any one person not want one of those? There’s no downside. Are customers telling them “I would love GPS and an accelerometer but give me a low resolution camera, not that high resolution crap!”?

Via Daring Fireball.

For two weeks starting from today every $10 you donate to my Ride to Cure Type 1 Diabetes fundraising campaign gets you the chance to win one of two great Mac software bundles worth almost $200 each! JDRF’s fundraising website lists donors and amounts so you know exactly how good your chances are. It’s no half assed bundle either, that’s 7 quality applications from reputable developers.

§ Sep 1st, 2009

Minimal Mac’s Menu Bar Vendetta

Almost once a day Minimal Mac features a post about how to cut stuff out of your menu bar. The most common removal is the time and date, then replaced by DateLine, a timeline style calendar that sits permanently on and spans the entire desktop. How that scores more minimalism points than the current date a click away in the menu bar, iCal or the dashboard, I don’t know.

Beside that, applications running in the menu bar has got to be the most unobtrusive, ‘minimalist’ option. I’ve seen unwieldy menu bars but the problem isn’t the menu bar, it’s running unused applications. Hiding the dock? Easy. Getting every icon off your desktop? Easy. Minimal Mac’s assault on the menu bar is minimalism for the sake of minimalism at the expense of utility and convenience.

§ Aug 30th, 2009

Universities

Commercial television in Australia is saturated with ads for two products: cars and universities. Griffith University releases a new advertising campaign every six months and runs it into the ground. UQ, QUT and Bond do the same. They don’t limit themselves to TV commercials, the campaign is spread across billboards, buses and stadium advertising. It must cost a lot of money.

Dr Mark Tarver has seen it first hand as a student and then a professor in Britain and I’ve experienced it as a student in Australia. Universities are far less about education than they are about making money. They’re not schools, they’re businesses selling an ‘education’ product but they’re even doing a bad job of that.

Like so many other businesses: PC makers and phone manufacturers, every car manufacturer, they have it backwards. Start with a shitty, out-dated campus, facilities and program, then reverse your unappealing experience and poor reputation by spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on saturation advertising.

Mount Royal College, the university I attended in Calgary was an incredible place. It was a beautiful, modern campus and residence that featured manicured sports fields, tennis courts, volley ball courts and a huge, olympic-class gym unlike any I have ever seen before or since. The gym included three indoor basketball courts, an indoor running track, an indoor 25 metre pool, hot tub, steam room, 8 squash courts, a climbing wall and a floor full of new, well maintained weight and cardio equipment. The cost to use these facilities for students: $0. It’s impossible to find equivalent facilities, university or otherwise, in my city no matter how much money you’re willing to spend. Facilities half as good cost $800/year.

Compare that with the gym facilities at Griffith University’s largest campus. A 40m2 room with very little, out-dated equipment. The cost to students already paying $3000+ each semester: $100. The difference in gym facilities is a perfect subset of the greater differences betweens schools here and overseas, particularly in North America.

Before you even think about education, Mount Royal is a place you want to be a part of. They start with great facilities and let natural appeal and reputation take care of the marketing. Rather than blow every last dollar on advertising, money is spent on what must be the far more satisfying task of creating a great place to work and study. Both lure students, one has the bonus of happy, involved student body. It’s no coincidence that the teaching and instruction I received at Mount Royal was also superior and my fellow students were more interested and studious.

I’m sure schools like Harvard and Yale in the USA don’t spend a dime on advertising. They’ve built a reputation for quality in all areas. They didn’t win that reputation through relentless advertising campaigns.

It’s frustrating when an app I use for 5 minutes every 6 months has both a time and feature limited demo. Amadeus Pro is an absolute joy to use but I can’t justify US$40 for something I need so rarely. I wish some shareware apps allowed very short rental periods. $2/day I’d pay.

§ Aug 27th, 2009

My gadgets tend to work and not break.

My gadgets tend to work and not break.

Like Marco my computer equipment, peripherals and gadgets tend to live long, healthy lives. I also rarely lose my keys or wallet but unlike Marco I was never poor or deprived, I put it down to being a careful person. It’s ridiculous the amount of people I know who have liquid spilt in laptop stories. I simply don’t have uncovered liquid near the laptop, ever.

In my case it extends to software. My computers and phone operate problem free while my friend’s and family’s equipment suffer a chronic barrage of issues. I don’t know what it is I’m doing differently but it works.

§ Aug 26th, 2009

Sharks vs. Cats

Sharks vs. Cats

When I first saw the cool avatar modification in my dashboard I couldn’t wait put my weight behind sharks or cats. But it’s not that simple, I can’t decide. I’m definitely not a cat person, they’re rude, selfish and exploit their owners. Sharks on the other hand make swimming in the ocean life threatening and eat seals, the dogs of the ocean. Both options are equally unappealing, I can’t choose.

§ Aug 26th, 2009

Ballad of the Beaconsfield Miners by Foo Fighters

I remember seeing Brant Webb and Todd Russell striding out of Beaconsfield Mine after 14 nights trapped in a their tiny underground cage. How they were able survive let alone come out looking so fresh and with such high spirits still amazes me.
